results.body:
A Virgin Atlantic Boeing passenger jet performs an emergency landing at Gatwick Airport after developing a landing gear fault, London.- AP

London: A Virgin Atlantic jet bound from London to Las Vegas turned back and made an emergency landing at Gatwick Airport on Monday after developing a problem with its landing gear.

The airline confirmed the Boeing 747-400, carrying 447 passengers and 15 crew members, landed safely about four hours after it took off. Television images showed the jet on the runway as fire trucks and ambulances waited nearby.

Gatwick said several passengers suffered minor injuries.

The incident caused major disruption to travelers. Gatwick said the airport's only runway would be closed until at least 6 p.m. (1 p.m. EST) as the Virgin plane was inspected. No flights were departing, and inbound flights were being diverted to other airports.

The airline said the plane undertook "a non-standard landing procedure" because of "a technical issue with one of the landing gears."

The airport said the flight, VS43, took off at about 11:45 a.m. Monday. Flight-tracking websites show it circled off the coast of southwest England before turning back to Gatwick, south of London. It circled near the airport, and photos appeared to show a set of wheels on its right-side landing gear had not fully descended.

Emergency services were on standby for the landing -- standard procedure when a plane has to land with a technical problem. The plane's emergency chutes were not deployed and passengers disembarked by stairs.

Passenger Mike Kaufman said the crew remained calm and professional throughout the four-hour crisis.

"Everybody gave the crew a big round of applause when we landed," he told Sky News from the plane.
results.title: Virgin Atlantic plane makes an emergency landing

results.body:
A WORCESTERSHIRE man has spoken of his relief after a 747 he was on had to make an emergency landing this afternoon.

The Virgin Atlantic jumbo jet made a dramatic, but safe, landing at Gatwick airport after developing a landing-gear fault.

Flight VS43, bound for Las Vegas, touched back down at the West Sussex just before 4pm.

The Boeing 747 jumbo jet returned to Gatwick after developing problems with its landing gear.

Virgin said: "Virgin Atlantic can confirm that the plane has landed safely at Gatwick. Our priority now is to look after our passengers."

Ambulances and fire-and-rescue crews had been on standby as the plane circled the airport in the hours after it took off for America in late morning.

Before the successful landing, Virgin announced that the plane would be carrying out a "non-standard landing procedure" at Gatwick airport.

Television pictures showed the plane at a halt safely on the runway.

There was apparently no need for an immediate response by emergency crews although within a few minutes the flashing lights of emergency vehicles could be seen close to the plane.

Pictures posted on Twitter of the aircraft circling Gatwick showed damage to the landing gear of the aircraft.

A dramatic photograph showed the jumbo jet landing at Gatwick with the right-side wing landing gear not deployed.

In November 1997 a Virgin Atlantic captain Tim Barnby won praise for safely landing a Virgin Atlantic Airbus plane at Heathrow after a landing-gear problem.

The plane, flying in from Los Angeles carrying 98 passengers and 16 crew, managed to touch down using three instead of four sets of landing gear.

Nine passengers were treated for minor injuries. Virgin said it had been "fantastic flying".

Describing the mood on the plane as it was circling, passenger Dan Crane, 24, from Bromsgrove, Worcestershire, said it was "anxious, a lot were worried, some crying. The mood was quiet and (we were) just waiting for the captain's next announcement."

Mr Crane, who is with family and friends, said the crew kept everyone informed, adding: "They said it was an emergency landing and we had to brace on impact."

Passenger Mike Kaufman, speaking from his seat on the plane back at Gatwick, said: "This was one of the greatest emergency landings in history. It was very smooth."

He praised the pilots and the cabin crew, saying the landing had been "textbook".

Interviewed for Sky News, he went on: "We didn't realise there would be such a fuss. It was such a calm, experience. About half an hour out they said we would have to go back to Gatwick. They said it was a hydraulic problem.

"The fact everything went so well shows just how professional the flight crew were. The crew were calm. We had a safety briefing two hours before we landed and when we were told we would have to go into the brace position for landings a sigh went around the plane."

Mr Kaufman continued: "People got used to the idea that we were going to have to land back at Gatwick. The crew were very calm and that made the passengers calm."
results.title: Safe landing after jumbo jet air drama

results.body:
The Boeing 747 jumbo jet was seen circling over the airport in West Sussex after the fault was reported.

The aircraft had been travelling to Las Vegas when the pilot made the decision to turn back.

A dramatic photograph showed the jumbo jet landing at Gatwick with the right-side wing landing gear not deployed.

Eyewitnesses reported that the jet was flying at a relatively low altitude and that the pilot appeared to be trying to shake the landing gear down.

It eventually touched down safely just before 4pm this afternoon, according to reports.

In a statement, Virgin said: "Virgin Atlantic can confirm that flight VS43 on December 29, travelling to McCarran International Airport Las Vegas, returned to Gatwick due to a technical issue with one of the landing gears.

"The aircraft is preparing to implement a non-standard landing procedure at Gatwick airport. A further update will be issued as soon as possible."

An airline spokesman later confirmed the jet had landed safely.

He said: "We can confirm that the plane has landed safely at Gatwick. Our priority now is to look after our passengers."

Ambulances and fire-and-rescue crews had been on standby as the plane circled the airport in the hours after it took off for America in late morning.

A spokesman for Gatwick airport said emergency services were put on standby "as a precaution".

He said: "We can confirm that Virgin Atlantic flight VS043 departed is returning to Gatwick after the aircraft developed a technical fault.

"In line with standard procedure, emergency services are on standby at the airport purely as a precaution."

Safe: the Virgin Atlantic Boeing 747 comes into land at Gatwick airport (Picture: Getty) In November 1997 a Virgin Atlantic captain Tim Barnby won praise for safely landing a Virgin Atlantic Airbus plane at Heathrow after a landing-gear problem.

The plane, flying in from Los Angeles carrying 98 passengers and 16 crew, managed to touch down using three instead of four sets of landing gear.

Nine passengers were treated for minor injuries. Virgin said it had been "fantastic flying".
results.title: Virgin Atlantic plane makes emergency landing at Gatwick Airport after technical fault

results.title: Branson hails jet pilots and crew

results.body:
Crying passengers on board a transatlantic flight have hailed a hero pilot after he was forced to perform an emergency landing on broken landing gear.

The Virgin Atlantic Boeing 747 with more than 450 people on board was meant to go to Las Vegas but was forced to return to London after developing a technical fault shortly after take-off.

For several hours the jumbo jet circled the airport and made several low-altitude passes so engineers could inspect the landing gear problem, leaving some passengers distraught as they were forced to adopt the brace position.

The plane finally landed with only three quarters of its landing gear down after a set of wheels on the starboard wing refused to drop.

Passenger Dan Crane, 24, from Bromsgrove, Worcestershire, said the mood before the landing was 'anxious'. He said: 'A lot were worried, some crying. They said it was an emergency landing and we had to brace on impact.'

But the terrified passengers then cheered and applauded the hero pilot - named only by passengers as 'Dave' - after he landed the jumbo jet safely with only a few on board suffering minor injuries.

Terrified passengers who had endured a nerve-racking few hours circling above the south coast after the problem was identified spoke of their relief as the pilot of Flight VS43 managed a 'textbook' landing.

Passengers, many heading for a New Year break in Las Vegas, adopted the brace position and emergency services were on standby as the giant aircraft, packed with 447 passengers and 15 crew, came into land.

And there was spontaneous applause as the pilot pulled off the delicate landing without a hitch and the jet rolled safely to a stop.

Describing the mood on the plane, Dan Crane, 24, from Bromsgrove, Worcestershire, said it was 'anxious, a lot were worried, some crying. The mood was quiet and (we were) just waiting for the captain's next announcement.'

Mr Crane, who was with family and friends, said the crew kept everyone informed, adding: 'They said it was an emergency landing and we had to brace on impact.'

The jet appeared to be flying with only three quarters of its landing gear down after a set of wheels on the starboard wing refused to drop, but the pilot still managed to land it safely.

The plane had to turn back towards London over the Devon coast less than 30 minutes after taking off for America at just before midday today.

The jet landed at Gatwick at 3.45pm today where it was met on the runway and surrounded by the emergency services.

Passengers on board were asked to adopt the brace position as the plane came in to land.

Mike Kaufman, who was on the plane, said it would go down as one of the 'greatest emergencies in history'.

He said: 'When we landed you can imagine the relief.

'We were told the plane had a hydraulic problem but were not told that it was the wheels.

'We were told about the brace position around two hours before we landed and ran through it several times before we landed. The crew were calm and that made us calm.

'The landing was smoother than others I've had. It was probably less dramatic on board than it was watching it on TV.

'It is going to go down as one of the greatest emergency landings in history'.

Newly-wed website user Alexia posted a picture of her and her husband earlier today as they went to board the flight, next to the message: 'We are on our way.'

But she later tweeted: 'Yup, that's my plane on the BBC News right now! #vegas #v043 will I ever get to Vegas??

After the plane landed, she wrote: 'Despite what we've just been through, we actually would quite like to get on another plane #VS43

'Biggest round of applause I've ever heard for a pilot landing. He's kept us informed the whole time of everything #VS43'

Other passengers also took to Twitter after touching down to thank the flight crew.

Kelly Coates tweeted: '#VS43 currently on board the Virgin Atlantic Flight VS43. Massive thank you to all of the crew for keeping everyone calm and safe ??'

Fate Swan wrote: '@virginatlantic the cabin crew and the pilot have been absolutely amazing and have been keeping us all calm and informed #VS43'

Another posted: 'Top marks to Dave the pilot and all the excellent Virgin cabin crew for bringing us back to Earth safe and sound. #vs43'.

A Gatwick Airport spokesman said: 'Virgin Atlantic flight VS043 has landed safely after returning to Gatwick due to a technical fault. Following the emergency landing, passengers have disembarked the aircraft via stairs. At this time, only minor injuries have been reported.

'The runway has been closed until the aircraft can be removed from the runway and based on current predictions it is not expected to reopen until at least 18.00. Currently no flights are departing Gatwick and inbound flights are being diverted to other airports. We advise passengers to check with their airlines on the status of their flight. Updates will also be posted on the Gatwick website and on Twitter.'

A Virgin Atlantic spokesman said: 'We can confirm that flight VS43 has landed safely back at Gatwick. Our priority now is to look after our passengers and crew'.

Chief Executive of Virgin Atlantic, Craig Kreeger, said: 'I understand that this will have been a very upsetting situation for the customers involved, and for their friends and family, and will have significantly disrupted people's holiday plans.

'We will make sure they are well looked after this evening, and will be operating a special flight tomorrow for everyone who would like to continue their journey.

'I'm here at Gatwick to meet our customers and crew, and to thank them all for their fantastic response. I understand that people have already been phoning our contact centre - from the plane - to make sure that they are booked on tomorrow's special flight to Las Vegas. I want to reassure them that we'll make sure there's a seat for everyone and we really look forward to making sure they're in Vegas for an amazing New Year's Eve.'

Before it landed the plane made at least one low-level pass over the London Gatwick so engineers could observe the problem.

Others who saw the jet circling around the airport said the pilot was 'tipping the wings' to try to use gravity to drop down the final part of the landing gear.

Ambulances and fire-and-rescue crews had been on standby as the plane circled the airport in the hours after it took off for the United States.

Before the successful landing, Virgin announced that the plane would be carrying out a 'non-standard landing procedure' at Gatwick airport =

A Gatwick Airport spokesman said: 'Virgin Atlantic flight VS043 has landed safely after returning to Gatwick due to a technical fault. Following the emergency landing, passengers have disembarked the aircraft via stairs. At this time, only minor injuries have been reported.

'The runway has been closed until the aircraft can be removed from the runway and based on current predictions it is not expected to reopen until at least 6pm.

'Currently no flights are departing Gatwick and inbound flights are being diverted to other airports.

We advise passengers to check with their airlines on the status of their flight. Updates will also be posted on the Gatwick website and on Twitter.'

A dramatic photograph showed the jumbo jet landing at Gatwick with the right-side wing landing gear not deployed.

In November 1997 a Virgin Atlantic captain Tim Barnby won praise for safely landing a Virgin Atlantic Airbus plane at Heathrow after a landing-gear problem.

The plane, flying in from Los Angeles carrying 98 passengers and 16 crew, managed to touch down using three instead of four sets of landing gear.
results.title: Virgin Boeing 747 on flight to Las Vegas returns to Gatwick

results.body:
The flight was heading to Las Vegas from Gatwick but was sent back to the Sussex airport with a 'technical problem'

Passengers onboard a Virgin Atlantic jumbo jet endured four hours of terror as its hero pilot desperately burned off fuel before making a dramatic emergency landing.

The packed plane was forced to circle over Gatwick after one set of wheels became stuck just minutes into the scheduled nine-hour flight to Las Vegas.

Hundreds of terrified revellers heading to the US city for New Year's Eve celebrations cried and prayed as they VS43 waited to land.

Emergency crews waited on the tarmac at Britain's second-busiest airport as the jumbo made two fly-pasts so that engineers to assess the problem.

Virgin flight attendants were told to carry out an unprecedented second safety briefing to all passengers before the emergency landing.

The plane eventually landed on three sets of main wheels with 447 passengers in the brace position more than four hours after taking off.

Relieved passengers, including families with small children, cheered and clapped as the pilot announced the landing had gone smoothly.

Airport bosses decided not to evacuate the aircraft and instead kept people onboard the plane while engineers checked the aircraft.

Read below for all the live updates and reaction to this story.

2:37 pm Flight circling Sussex

A Virgin Atlantic Flight that was due to head to the US is circling above Heathrow - 'with its landing gear locked' eye witnesses claim.

The London Gatwick to Las Vegas flight set off from Sussex this morning but only got as far as the south west of England when it began a holding pattern above Devon and Cornwall.

It was then redirected to Gatwick but has now been seen circling the airport, apparently unable to land.

Eye witnesses have taken pictures of the plane and claim that the landing gear is locked in position.

The company has confirmed the plane has a 'technical problem' and the redirection is a 'precautionary measure'.

2:39 pm Company statement - 'precautionary measure'

Virgin Atlantic has confirmed there is a problem with the flight but says the redirection is a 'precautionary measure'.

A spokeswoman said: "Our Las Vegas flight turnback is actually a precautionary measure because of a small technical problem.

"We're expecting it back at Gatwick very shortly and after that time I can send you an updated statement including plans to rearrange the flight for passengers."

2:41 pm Picture of plane

A number of eyewitnesses have posted pictures of the troubled plane online.

Multiple tweeters say the plane has been circling overhead.

Others claim the landing gear is 'locked', though that isn't clear from their pictures.

#VS43 over Haywards Heath. Seems to attempt emergency landing now or flyover. pic.twitter.com/k0DzwqtZxP -- Andreas Farina Vaz (@AndreasVaz)

December 29, 2014

2:42 pm Holding patterns

This was the flight took when it began a holding pattern off the south west coast.

The flight VS43 had been heading to Las Vegas but stopped making progress just after passing over Devon.

It began circling several times before being redirected to Gatwick where it began circling again.

#VS43 flew over Gatwick at 2275 feet and is now holding south of the airport http://t.co/0lDFiUJBri pic.twitter.com/8VuJfo9o4i -- Flightradar24 (@flightradar24)

December 29, 2014

2:48 pm Flight at 1,275 feet

Flight Radar is keeping tracking of the flights journey as it appears to be experiencing a problem.

The flight has reportedly at around 1,275 feet after making another pass over the airport.

As you can see from the image the flight has made repeated circles around Gatwick.

#VS43 flew over Gatwick again. This time on 1275 feet. Still no confirmed information about the problem. pic.twitter.com/kcbGXAx4uU -- Flightradar24 (@flightradar24)

December 29, 2014

2:50 pm Plane 'was on final approach'

This picture shows the flight clearly, with the landing gear down.

According to witnesses this was the plane on final approach but the flight has yet to land.

Instead it is still circling the airport.

#VS43 on final approach to Gatwick http://t.co/0lDFiUJBri RT @WILLIE747HUNT: @flightradar24 pic.twitter.com/bQYySZVDR8 -- Flightradar24 (@flightradar24)

December 29, 2014

2:52 pm Plane is now flying south towards coast

The plane is now flying south towards the coast.

A grab from flight radar in the last few minutes shows the plane going over Brighton.

There is speculation that it could be dumping fuel.

@flightradar24 #VS43 climbing and moving off towards English Channel... Dumping fuel? pic.twitter.com/mQjaXX8VOD -- Thomas Preston (@ThomasRPreston)

December 29, 2014

2:56 pm 'Right wing gear not down'

It is now being reported that the right wing gear is not down.

This would explain why the flight is apparently having trouble landing even with part of the landing gear down.

The plane has reportedly made a number of attempted approaches to land at Gatwick before heading south.

"@airlivenet: Virgin Atlantic #VS43 Right wing gear not down!!! Boeing 747 Track: http://t.co/RMtOI48USY pic.twitter.com/gRaxfESG7b" @RWMann -- Bruce Almich (@Balmich)

December 29, 2014

2:58 pm Emergency services 'heading to Gatwick'

Emergency services have been spotted, it is believed on their way to Gatwick airport.

Tweeter 'James' wrote that he saw 'tons' of vehicles heading in the airport's direction.

However, the latest flight path shows the plane heading towards the English Channel.

Driving back from #Crawley watching tons of emergency services heading to what I assume is Gatwick to aid in the #vs43 situation -- James (@xHATEx)

December 29, 2014

3:01 pm Video of flight path

This video clip shows the flight path so far of Virgin Atlantic flight VS43.

The plane was supposed to have been going from Gatwick to Las Vegas.

Instead it circled off the south west coast off Devon before heading back to the airport.

3:02 pm 'Technical issue but not an emergency' says Gatwick

A spokeswoman for Gatwick Airport confirmed that an outward bound flight had suffered 'a technical issue' but was not able to elaborate.

She said the fight affected was the Virgin Atlantic flight VS043 which left Gatwick for Las Vegas at 1.20pm today.

She added: "I would not call it an emergency. We have flights affected by technical issues all the time."

3:05 pm Circling over Brighton coast

In the last 10 minutes the plane has flown over head office of The Argus newspaper in Brighton.

The flight VS43 has flown over Seaford, has now turned and is coming back over Newhaven, Saltdean and Brighton according to flightradar.

This is the third location the flight has circled over, after Gatwick and the coast off Devon.

#VS43 from London to Las Vegas http://t.co/4GK3ixbaB8 lapping over Brighton trying to 'gravity drop' landing gear pic.twitter.com/HPWrjAjq3i -- Trevor Langworth (@TLangworth)

December 29, 2014

3:06 pm Plane seen 'shaking'

An eye witness claims to have seen the plane 'shaking'.

Tweeter James, says that while driving on the A27 he could see the movement of the aircraft clearly.

He believes this is an attempt to free the 'locked landing gear'.

Just passing #vs43 whilst on the A27 can clearly see the plane shaking in an attempt to free the locked gear -- James (@xHATEx)

December 29, 2014

3:11 pm Plane now at 5,300ft

The flight is now at around 5,300ft it has been reported.

Flightradar shows the plane continuing to make small circles over Newhaven in Sussex.

Speed is around 200 knots.

VS43 from London to Las Vegas http://t.co/NUKG7zEot0 still circling over newhaven at 5300ft pic.twitter.com/pWso4BCw8y -- gareth evans (@gareth0108)

December 29, 2014

3:13 pm Fire service on standby

A spokesman for Sussex Fire and Rescue Service confirmed that they had been placed 'on standby'.

Emergency services were understood to be meeting at a designated rendezvous point near Gatwick Airport.

Earlier a witness reported seeing unspecified emergency vehicles heading towards the airport.

3:15 pm Flight is 'preparing to implement a non-standard landing'

A Virgin spokesman said: "Virgin Atlantic can confirm that flight VS43 on 29 December, travelling to McCarran International Airport Las Vegas, returned to London Gatwick due to a technical issue with one of the landing gears.

"The aircraft is preparing to implement a non-standard landing procedure at Gatwick airport.

"A further update will be issued as soon as possible."

3:16 pm Plane made multiple passes at Gatwick

Flight VS043 made at least two low level passes over Gatwick's control tower where staff using binoculars studied its undercarriage.

It is believed that the aircraft has a problem with a wheel under its right wing, which will either not lower or lock into position.

The jet is believed to have around 400 passengers onboard.

There are currently 20 ambulances on standby at the airport with more expected from the London Ambulance and the South Central Ambulance Service.

3:19 pm Close up picture of landing gear

We now have an very close up picture of the landing gear on the plane.

Multiple eye witnesses have claimed the problem is with the landing gear not working properly on one side.

Virgin has confirmed in the last few minutes the plane is to make a 'non standard' landing.

#VS43 RT @SamPilcher: From the back of my camera the state of VIR43Es undercarriage on its fly. pic.twitter.com/Sd7O0QoP8l -- Flightradar24 (@flightradar24)

December 29, 2014

3:23 pm Police helicopter on scene

A police helicopter is reportedly in a holding pattern itself, to the south of the airport.

Samuel Pilcher, an aeronautical engineering student, has claimed there is a road block reading to shut a perimeter road at Gatwick.

This would suggest the airport is readying for the 'non standard landing' Virgin has confirmed.

Police 37, helicopter is holding to the south of Gatwick. Road block readying to shut the perimeter road past the 08 end of the runway. -- Samuel Pilcher (@SamPilcher)

December 29, 2014

3:26 pm 'More than 20 ambulances at scene'

More than 20 ambulances are at the scene with more en-route, as well as other emergency services, it has been reported.

The 747, due to fly to Las Vegas, flew over tower several times, with staff using binoculars to view undercarriage.

Officials believe it is likely the undercarriage will collapse when landing.

3:33 pm Previous emergency landing at Heathrow

This wouldn't be the first time a UK flight has had to make a 'non standard' landing due to undercarriage problems.

In 1997 a Virgin Atlantic flight had to make a landing at Heathrow following an emergency.

The pilot Captain Tim Barnaby was praised for bringing the plane to safe landing without injuring any of the 97 passengers on board.

Below you can see video footage of the incident.

3:36 pm Plane 'readying for landing'

The flight VS43 is now readying for its landing at Gatwick it is being reported.

Aviation student Samuel Pilcher says the plane is preparing for the final approach to land at runway 26L.

The plane has travelling back north after circling the Brighton area for the last half hour.

VIR43E is now vectoring for his final approaches to runway 26L with 25 miles to run. -- Samuel Pilcher (@SamPilcher)

December 29, 2014

3:41 pm 'Five minutes to landing'

Emergency vehicles are at Gatwick airport, prepared and ready.

Below is the latest flight path as the plane headed towards Gatwick.

The plane is reportedly five minutes away from the attempted landing.

Virgin Atlantic flight #VS43 is heading for Gatwick again. Emergency vehicles are waiting at the airport. pic.twitter.com/ApwcBf2xcR -- Flightradar24 (@flightradar24)

December 29, 2014

3:42 pm Emergency services on standby

A Gatwick Airport spokesman said: "We can confirm that Virgin Atlantic flight VS043 which departed Gatwick Airport at around 11.45am is returning to Gatwick after the aircraft developed a technical fault.

"In line with standard procedure, emergency services are on standby at the airport purely as a precaution."

The plane is reportedly minutes away from the attempted landing.

3:45 pm Flight is the next to land

The plane is the next to land at Gatwick.

Fire crews are understood to be in place.

Passengers have been in the air for more than three hours at this point.

VIR43E next to land with 16 miles to run, 5 minutes out. Fire crews in place. -- Samuel Pilcher (@SamPilcher)

December 29, 2014

3:47 pm Plane is approaching the runaway

The plane is coming into land now, with the faulty landing gear in place.

Emergency services will be on scene if the worst comes to the worst.

We will hopefully know whether the landing has been a success in the next few minutes.

High drama with #VS43 coming in to land right now at Gatwick with faulty landing gear. -- Ian Aitchison (@IanAitchison)

December 29, 2014

3:48 pm Plane has landed successfully

And thankfully it appears that the plane has landed safely.

In the last few moments the Virgin Atlantic plane has come to a stop on the tarmac at Gatwick.

We'll bring you pictures as soon as we can get them.

3:50 pm Safe landing at Gatwick

After dramatic scenes in the skies above the south of England the plane has landed safely.

Emergency services were on scene in case things went badly but fortunately the flight appears to have landed without incident.

It's not known yet what will happen to the passengers on board, who had been expecting to land in Las Vegas later this evening.

High drama with #VS43 coming in to land right now at Gatwick with faulty landing gear. -- Ian Aitchison (@IanAitchison)

December 29, 2014

3:52 pm Picture from the scene

Here's the first picture from the scene at Gatwick now that the plane has landed.

The flight, with several hundred passengers on board, touched down in the last few minutes.

It had to carry out a 'non-standard' landing, potentially due to as-yet unconfirmed reports about faulty landing gear.

Looks like #VS43 landed safely pic.twitter.com/RfsXajqhGC -- Jason Dugdale (@dugjason)

December 29, 2014

3:55 pm Picture of landed plane

Here's another picture now of the safely landed plane.

It was a dramatic landing after the Las Vegas bound flight left Gatwick this morning only to land back there this afternoon.

Virgin Atlantic says there was a 'technical problem' and that the rerouting was a 'precautionary measure'.

BREAKING PHOTO: Virgin Atlantic #VS43 safely on the ground at Gatwick airport following partial landing gear failure pic.twitter.com/Z8m35LfMoE -- Lisa Daftari (@LisaDaftari)

December 29, 2014

3:58 pm Gatwick 'may remain closed for some time'

There is speculation that Gatwick may remain closed 'for some time' following the landing.

No other flights were able to land while the sky-high drama was being played out.

This may well mean knock on delays for other flights due to come into or depart the busy Sussex airport.

Gatwick Airport will probably remain closed for some time. pic.twitter.com/EXUJ6aE2q1 -- Flightradar24 (@flightradar24)

December 29, 2014

4:02 pm Praise for pilot

There's been universal praise for the pilot who brought the passenger plane down safely.

Following the recent Asian air tragedies there will be relief all round this flight didn't go the same way.

Despite apparently faulty landing gear, the pilot landed VS43 smoothly by all accounts.

Well done #VirginAtlantic VS43, shows how highly trained you guys are. -- aileen cooper (@lavenderbluewed)

December 29, 2014

4:05 pm Virgin confirms safe landing

The airline has now confirmed the flight has landed safely.

A spokeswoman said: "Virgin Atlantic can confirm that flight VS43 has landed safely back at Gatwick.

"Our priority now is to look after our passengers and crew."

4:07 pm Video footage of plane on the ground

Here's the first video footage of the plane having landed safely at Gatwick in the last 10 minutes.

The passenger flight successfully executed a non-standard landing procedure after circling for hours.

Emergency services were on hand 'as a precaution'.

4:12 pm First tweets from passengers

One of the first passengers has tweeted after the safe landing.

Sunjay Patel, a media recruitment consultant, described the situation as 'a bit of drama'.

The flight appears to have been a birthday surprise for him.

@matt_shoreditch @robertrea everyone seems to be fine. We are going to be leaving the plane soon. Hopefully to board another plane #VS43 -- SunjayPatel (@SunjayPatel)

December 29, 2014

4:16 pm Couple on plane tweet picture

One couple posted this picture before the plane took off, five hours ago.

Alexia, a newly wed from Walthamstow, has posted a number of messages since landing safely.

She said that despite what they've just gone through the couple would quite like to get on another plane.

We are on our way @49andcounting pic.twitter.com/bO6bDBxADK -- Alexia (@alexia_g88)

December 29, 2014

4:20 pm Video of flight path

Here's another video now, of the flight path taken by the Virgin Atlantic flight.

The Flight Radar website has charted the route, which began at London Gatwick and should have gone on to Las Vegas.

Instead, five hours later, the plane is back at its original departure point.

4:22 pm Non standard procedure was 'rare occurrence'

The plane landed on a 'non-standard procedure', which could potentially have been fatal, according to plane spotter Nicholas Hair.

He said the incident was a 'rare occurrence'.

The 20-year-old railway worker said: "One of the engines failed or stopped which can happen sometimes, and as the plane has got four engines, it can use three."

"However, it has caused a hydraulic leak so the landing gear will not come down.

"When landing the plane, it will be like driving a car with the back wheel falling off. Anytime there is a landing gear fault, it is an unsafe landing.

"This is a rare occurrence and I have not heard about something like this happening before."

4:24 pm Passengers thank staff

Passengers have been thanking the staff on the flight for landing the plane safely.

One of them, Alexia, says the staff were 'amazing the whole way'.

She added that she had thanked them face to face.

@JPDoy 100% the staff were amazing the whole way through. We've actually said thank you face to face -- Alexia (@alexia_g88)

December 29, 2014

4:26 pm Ambulance statement

Emergency services were called out the incident but fortunately don't appear to have been needed.

A spokesman for South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust said: "The trust was alerted to a potential incident at Gatwick Airport today involving an aircraft which was forced to make an emergency landing.

"The Trust was alerted to a potential issue with a Virgin Atlantic flight at 12.45pm.

"The Trust has robust and well-rehearsed plans in place to manage such incidents and moved a number of vehicles into the area should they have been required, including our Hazardous Area Response Team (HART) and specialist paramedics.

"As far as we are aware at present, no passengers or crew require medical attention, although some clinicians will remain on scene until the incident is closed."

4:28 pm Video of the safe landing

A member of the public has filmed the incredible safe landing of the Virgin Atlantic flight.

This footage shows the passenger plane that had to make a 'non-standard' landing after circling various points in the south of England for hours.

Passengers have been praising the pilot for their sterling effort in avoiding any apparent injury this afternoon.

4:30 pm Ambulances not needed

Fortunately the ambulance service was not needed in the end.

But if they had been they would have been in good time, as they prepared for the unplanned landing at Gatwick.

Below is a tweet of some of the responders who were called out to the site this afternoon.

Both Gatwick and Ashford teams in attendance at ##gatwick Virgin plane incident. No medical emergencies to report pic.twitter.com/FaIm0IyecB -- SECAmb HART (@SECAmbHart)

December 29, 2014

4:32 pm Round of applause for pilot

The pilot had a round of applause from passengers when the plane landed safely.

One passenger, Alexia from Walthamstow, tweeted that it was the biggest she'd heard.

She added that she never thought she would have to use the brace position.

Biggest round of applause I've ever heard for a pilot landing. He's kept us informed the whole time of everything #VS43 -- Alexia (@alexia_g88)

December 29, 2014

4:33 pm Passengers 'in safe hands'

Passenger Mike Kaufman told Sky News how the passengers were "in safe hands" throughout the journey.

He said they had to adopt the brace position as they came into land.

"The landing was smoother than others we've had," Mr Kaufman told reporters.

"It did slow down a bit more than normal.

"The whole crew and pilot remained very calm. We didn't realise there had been such a fuss because it was such a calm experience."

4:34 pm 'Queue for the toilets when we landed'

Describing the moment passengers were told what was going on passenger Mike Kaufman said: "It was about 30 mins to one hour into the flight and we were told we had to go back to Gatwick.

"They said it was a hydraulic problem - not particularly the wheels. I was hoping that wouldn't be the case.

"The crew and pilot were so professional. All passengers kept calm because they were calm.

"There was a bit of a queue for toilets for a while because we had been sitting in our seats for a while."

Mike described the moment the plane prepared to finally land.

He said: "We we were given a safety briefing two hours before and then reminded shortly before.

"As we came into land you feel nervous. We just wanted it to be over and done with. We thought it was going to be fine but you're just never sure.

"We talked about going on a rollercoaster when we got to Vegas - that's not going to happen now. Thank god the crew and pilot knew what they were doing."

4:36 pm 'Lots of worry, some crying'

Describing the mood on the plane as it was circling, passenger Dan Crane, 24, from Bromsgrove, Worcestershire, said it was "anxious, a lot were worried, some crying.

"The mood was quiet and (we were) just waiting for the captain's next announcement."

Mr Crane, who is with family and friends, said the crew kept everyone informed, adding: "They said it was an emergency landing and we had to brace on impact."

4:38 pm 'Passengers leaving 70 at a time to stabilise plane'

Passengers have reportedly been leaving 70 at a time - to make sure the plane stays stable.

One passenger called Alexia described the scene as the no-doubt relieved passengers left the plane.

She hopes to be able to fly to Las Vegas tomorrow.

Leaving the plane 70 at a time to keep plane stabilised and hopefully able to fly tomorrow. Very thankful right now! #VS43 -- Alexia (@alexia_g88)

December 29, 2014

4:43 pm Check with your airline for delays

Anyone flying from Gatwick today is advised to check with their airline for potential delays.

There is a likely knock on effect from the non-standard landing of the Virgin flight this afternoon.

The aircraft is now being reviewed and the passengers have been disembarking.

Virgin flight VS043 landed safely, the aircraft is being reviewed and passengers are disembarking. Check with your airline for flight delays -- Gatwick Airport LGW (@Gatwick_Airport)

December 29, 2014

4:46 pm Other flights diverted to Luton and Stansted

Some of the other flights due to arrive in Gatwick are expected to be redirected to other airports as a result of the dramatic landing.

According to Flight radar this is likely to include Stansted and Luton as opposed to Heathrow.

If you're due to pick someone up at the airport today its best to check with their airline for the latest updates.

Map of all flights scheduled to Gatwick. Looks like most will divert to Stansted and Luton http://t.co/c73S3SXxQl pic.twitter.com/35vzhp4gQa -- Flightradar24 (@flightradar24)

December 29, 2014

4:49 pm Passenger pictures as they leave plane

One passenger has posted a number of pictures of the scene that awaited them as they departed the plane.

Anthony Barnes, from Manchester, took this and other shots as he stepped onto the tarmac in the last half hour.

Emergency services were all on hand just in case the landing ended badly.

Coming off at gatwick #VS43 @VirginAtlantic pic.twitter.com/p0NBfQxNtH -- Anthony Barnes (@Rhubarb84)

December 29, 2014

4:51 pm Close up shot of the plane

Another picture from Tweeter and passenger Anthony Barnes now.

Here you can see the relieved passengers walking across the tarmac as they left they plane.

Airport staff are in hi vis jackets helping them off.

pic.twitter.com/FWkm9nVNLw -- Anthony Barnes (@Rhubarb84)

December 29, 2014

4:56 pm Textbook landing

Terrified passengers applauded a hero pilot after he landed a Virgin Atlantic jumbo jet safely at Gatwick airport after a major landing-gear fault.

Travellers who had endured a nerve-racking few hours circling above the south coast after the problem was identified spoke of their relief as the pilot of Flight VS43 managed a "textbook" landing despite one of the plane's five sets of landing gear not deploying.

Passengers, many heading for a New Year break in Las Vegas, adopted the brace position and emergency services were on standby as the giant aircraft, packed with 447 passengers and 15 crew, came into land.

5:01 pm Zero casualties

The local ambulance service has confirmed there were zero casualties following the plane landing.

These pictures below show the dramatic scenes on the Gatwick tarmac as services rallied to help anyone that needed it.

Fortunately, the paramedics were not needed.

Scene pics from earlier. Can confirm zero reported casualties minor or major at this time #ukhart #gatwickairport pic.twitter.com/FB70FsMHvY -- SECAmb HART (@SECAmbHart)

December 29, 2014

5:04 pm Top marks for 'Dave the pilot'

One passenger has tweeted that the pilot deserves 'top marks' for the save landing.

The tweeter said he and his partner had survived the flight this afternoon.

He also referred to the pilot as 'Dave' - we don't know his surname yet.

Me and the mrs have just survived the Virgin emergency landing at Gatwick! Yikes! Thunder sfp #vs43 -- Steroid Freak Pussy (@steroidfreakpsy)

December 29, 2014

5:05 pm Is flying safe?

The disappearance of AirAsia Flight QZ8501 between Indonesia and Singapore this weekend capped a scary year in aviation: think of Air Algerie Flight AH5017, Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, TransAsia GE222, Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17.

Today there were more scares after a Virgin Atlantic flight was sent back to Gatwick Airport after problems with the landing gear.

They say that flying is the safest way to travel, but watching the news is getting rather scary. Is that fear borne out by the facts?

Click here to look at the data before running off to cancel your flights.

5:07 pm More plane pictures

Another picture of the scene on the tarmac now.

One of the passengers, Alexia, posted this image having safely made it onto the ground.

She's due to continue her journey to Las Vegas tomorrow after a good nights sleep.

Terra firma #vs43 pic.twitter.com/C8xkQu2XIZ -- Alexia (@alexia_g88)

December 29, 2014

5:12 pm Plane pictured

There's a nice picture here of the plane having reached the ground safely.

This was earlier when there was still some daylight - the passengers appear to have been evacuated from the plane after dark.

No news yet on what will happen to the plane following the dramatic scenes this afternoon.

Happy ending!! ✈️ MT"@airlivenet: PHOTO Boeing 747 #VS43 Gatwick Emergency Landing pic.twitter.com/E9uOcRfhBV /@USofGB" -- ✈Monica-✈ (@vargasmoni)

December 29, 2014

5:17 pm Minor injuries reported

A Gatwick airport spokesman said some passengers suffered minor injuries and runway was closed until at least 6pm.

He said: "Virgin Atlantic flight VS043 has landed safely after returning to Gatwick due to a technical fault.

"Following the emergency landing, passengers have disembarked the aircraft via stairs. At this time, only minor injuries have been reported.

"The runway has been closed until the aircraft can be removed from the runway and, based on current predictions, it is not expected to reopen until at least 6pm.

"Currently no flights are departing Gatwick and inbound flights are being diverted to other airports.

"We advise passengers to check with their airlines on the status of their flight. Updates will also be posted on the Gatwick website and on Twitter."

5:34 pm Richard Branson praises pilot and staff for safe landing

Virgin boss Richard Branson has offered his praise to the pilot and staff for ensuring a 'safe and skillful' landing landing.

Writing on Twitter he said: "Thoughts with passengers and crew, thanks for support and patience."

Only minor injuries have been reported.

Well done @virginatlantic pilots & team for safe & skillful landing of #VS43. Thoughts with passengers & crew, thanks for support & patience -- Richard Branson (@richardbranson)

December 29, 2014

5:41 pm Amateur footage of emergency landing

Rhys Matthews was an eye witness to the plane landing this afternoon.

An accounts manager for Westoncon, he works on the fourth floor of an eight-storey building on the landing approach to Gatwick.

He put together the video below showing the happy ending to the dramatic story.

Mr Matthews, 22, said: "It was very dramatic. The plane was coming in much slower than normal.

"My colleague works for Virgin and was listening to their comms. They were saying 'pan pan pan' which means there's a problem with the plane but no lives are in danger.

"It was a very low approach."

5:47 pm Calm landing

Mr Matthews said that when the plane did come in, it appeared to be much like a normal landing.

He said: "We were about a mile away, and it was very calmly gliding in.

"The whole office was up against the window. For about an hour we were checking to see where the plane would go - whether it would go to Heathrow or somewhere else.

"That's a good way of gauging how serious an incident it was."

5:49 pm Well trained staff

Mr Matthews is a former cabin crew member himself, having previously for a BMI.

Although he never had an emergency landing, he like all airline staff are trained to deal with such situations.

He said: "You go by what your captain and crew manager says.

"You don't want to cause panic - unnecessary panic when he was landing would have scared people.

"You have to be honest though - they [the passengers] will have noticed.

"Staff will have had huge experience and Virgin does very good training. They were probably very calm."

5:55 pm Ambulance service has now left the scene

The local ambulance service has now left the scene.

This tweet was posted in the last half hour, showing the remaining ambulances at the plane landing site.

Fortunately for all involved, paramedics weren't needed.

All HART assets standing down. No injuries. pic.twitter.com/QurebvnzbW -- SECAmb HART (@SECAmbHart)

December 29, 2014

6:03 pm 'No real risk' of injury

There was "no real risk" of injury to the passengers of the Virgin Atlantic jumbo jet after it developed a landing-gear fault, an aviation expert has said.

David Learmount, Flight Global's operations and safety editor, said the plane had a problem with one of its gear legs, of which there are five - two under the body, one under each wing and one in the nose.

He said: "There is a light for each of those and if one of them doesn't come on fully then they have to get rid of as much fuel as they can then land with as many gears down as they can land with."

He added: "If it was really serious they could land with no wheels at all."

6:10 pm Circling to get rid of fuel

Flight VS43, bound for Las Vegas, made a safe landing at Gatwick airport just before 4pm.

The aeroplane would have had to circle to get rid of fuel before it landed, Mr Learmount said.

"You're not going to take any chances. You want to have as little fuel as possible on board because fuel burns so you get rid of it."

Using up fuel also makes the plane less heavy, which Mr Learmount said would reduce the risk of gear collapse.

Mr Learmount compared a gear fault to a mechanical problem on an ironing board: "You're putting up your ironing board and you find that when you put the leg round against the stop, the stop is loose and so the ironing board is not stable, so one of the components which provides a mechanical lock to keep it down or up is not doing the job it's supposed to do."

6:17 pm 'Zero chance of getting hurt'

The crew would not have known there was a problem with the gear before they set off, he explained.

"If you knew before you set off, you wouldn't set off, but I suspect that the first time that they knew about it was after take off when they tried to pull the gear up and something didn't work exactly as it should do," he said.

Mr Learmount said pilots are trained to be able to deal with this sort of fault.

He said: "There was no real risk. A few times a year a plane lands with one gear leg not extended or something like that, and sometimes they say it is worse to do that and land lopsided than land with all the gears up."

He added: "The chances of this happening are pretty low and if it does the chances of you getting hurt are almost zero, even if the gear fails completely."

Asked how frequently this sort of fault occurs, Mr Learmount said: "I should think a couple of times a year for all the airlines in the UK."

6:21 pm Virgin chief exec praise

Virgin Atlantic chief executive Craig Kreeger said: "I am very pleased to confirm that all customers and crew have now disembarked the VS43 flight to Las Vegas, which returned to Gatwick airport this afternoon following a problem with one of the landing gear.

"I understand that this will have been a very upsetting situation for the customers involved, and for their friends and family, and will have significantly disrupted people's holiday plans. We will make sure they are well looked after this evening, and will be operating a special flight tomorrow for everyone who would like to continue their journey."

He went on: "I'm here at Gatwick to meet our customers and crew, and to thank them all for their fantastic response. I understand that people have already been phoning our contact centre - from the plane - to make sure that they are booked on tomorrow's special flight to Las Vegas.

"I want to reassure them that we'll make sure there's a seat for everyone and we really look forward to making sure they're in Vegas for an amazing New Year's Eve.

"I would like to thank all of the Virgin Atlantic crew and colleagues, who responded with the absolute professionalism and care for our customers that we would expect."

6:36 pm Brace position

Passenger Hardeek Desai told BBC News that the passengers were told the fault was "hydraulic", that fuel would be coming out of the right wing, and that this was a normal procedure.

He said passengers were told 10 to 15 minutes in advance that they would have to adopt the brace position on landing.

"For my mind, personally, I was a bit worried, thinking what's going to happen. It doesn't really seem normal that fuel is coming out of the wing. I was slightly worried but just trying to keep calm and listen to what the staff were telling us.

"Around 30 seconds before we actually hit the ground, we were told to adopt the brace.

"At that stage it was literally just everyone shouting 'brace' and people just screaming and shouting. Everyone was a bit worried about what was going on.

6:58 pm Balpa chairman praise

Balpa chairman Captain Brendan O'Neal said: "These pilots have had to put into practise their years of training and experience to keep their aircraft and passengers safe today. They did a very professional job in difficult circumstances.

"Pilots across the UK and across all airlines know that although incidents like this are rare, they could happen to any of us, and we have huge respect for the crews who fly with such skill and professionalism when it is needed.

"On behalf of the British Airline Pilots' Association, I want to pay tribute to the crew for keeping the passengers on this flight safe."

He said he was confident the cause of the landing gear failure would be identified quickly and resolved.

7:13 pm Live coverage concluded

Our live coverage of the Virgin Atlantic mid-air drama has now come to an end.

After five hours in the air, passengers were relieved to have landed at Gatwick safely.

Their flight had been travelling to Las Vegas from London Gatwick when it developed problems with the landing gear.

After several hours of circling over the south of England and fuel burning, the plane attempted an emergency landing at the airport it had left from.

Passengers have described how afraid many of the more than 400 people on board were as the staff told them to assume the brace position.

Fortunately though, the skilled pilot was able to bring the plane down in what was described as a 'textbook landing'.
results.title: Virgin Atlantic VS43 emergency: Live updates as passenger plane

results.body:
THE Boeing 747 flight heading for America returned to Gatwick after developing problems with undercarriage landing gear.

A VIRGIN Atlantic jumbo jet has made a dramatic, but safe, landing at Gatwick airport after developing a landing-gear fault.

Flight VS43, bound for Las Vegas, touched back down at the West Sussex just before 4pm.

The Boeing 747 jumbo jet returned to Gatwick after developing problems with its landing gear.

Virgin said: "Virgin Atlantic can confirm that the plane has landed safely at Gatwick. Our priority now is to look after our passengers."

Ambulances and fire-and-rescue crews had been on standby as the plane circled the airport in the hours after it took off for America in late morning.

Before the successful landing, Virgin announced that the plane would be carrying out a "non-standard landing procedure" at Gatwick airport.

Television pictures showed the plane at a halt safely on the runway.

There was apparently no need for an immediate response by emergency crews although within a few minutes the flashing lights of emergency vehicles could be seen close to the plane.

Pictures posted on Twitter of the aircraft circling Gatwick showed damage to the landing gear of the aircraft.

A dramatic photograph showed the jumbo jet landing at Gatwick with the right-side wing landing gear not deployed.

In November 1997 a Virgin Atlantic captain Tim Barnby won praise for safely landing a Virgin Atlantic Airbus plane at Heathrow after a landing-gear problem.

The plane, flying in from Los Angeles carrying 98 passengers and 16 crew, managed to touch down using three instead of four sets of landing gear.

Nine passengers were treated for minor injuries. Virgin said it had been "fantastic flying".

Describing the mood on the plane as it was circling, passenger Dan Crane, 24, from Bromsgrove, Worcestershire, said it was "anxious, a lot were worried, some crying. The mood was quiet and (we were) just waiting for the captain's next announcement."

Mr Crane, who is with family and friends, said the crew kept everyone informed, adding: "They said it was an emergency landing and we had to brace on impact."

Passenger Mike Kaufman, speaking from his seat on the plane back at Gatwick, said: "This was one of the greatest emergency landings in history. It was very smooth."

He praised the pilots and the cabin crew, saying the landing had been "textbook".

Interviewed for Sky News, he went on: "We didn't realise there would be such a fuss. It was such a calm, experience. About half an hour out they said we would have to go back to Gatwick. They said it was a hydraulic problem.

"The fact everything went so well shows just how professional the flight crew were. The crew were calm. We had a safety briefing two hours before we landed and when we were told we would have to go into the brace position for landings a sigh went around the plane."

From the back of my camera the state of VIR43Es undercarriage on its fly. pic.twitter.com/HDWhwReMG1 -- Samuel Pilcher (@SamPilcher)

December 29, 2014

Mr Kaufman continued: "People got used to the idea that we were going to have to land back at Gatwick. The crew were very calm and that made the passengers calm."

Asked what was going through his mind, Mr Kaufman said: "People in the row with me were saying 'We want this over and done with'. We thought we'd be fine but you're never sure.

"Everybody gave the crew a big round of applause when we landed. I can't wait to get into the terminal and have a gin and tonic now

"We were talking about going on a rollercoaster ride when we got to Las Vegas. Now I'm not so sure."

A spokesman for British pilots' organisation Balpa said: "There appears to have been a technical problem with the landing gear but the pilot seems to have done a very professional job in getting the plane down safely.

"Pilots train hard for exactly this kind of situation. It goes to show that well-trained pilots are vital."
results.title: Virgin Atlantic flight suffering landing gear problems lands safely at Gatwick

results.body:
A Virgin Atlantic jumbo jet has made a dramatic, but safe, landing at Gatwick airport after developing a landing-gear fault.

Flight VS43, bound for Las Vegas, touched back down at the West Sussex just before 4pm.

The Boeing 747 jumbo jet returned to Gatwick after developing problems with its landing gear.

Reports in the national media suggested that flight VS43 was ordered to fly low over Southampton Airport so staff could see the landing gear, to determine if it was stuck.

This however has now been denied by the National Air Traffic Service (NATS), which are based at Swanwick, near Fareham.

The flight did indeed fly over Southampton, but not for an inspection.

The plane flying over Sussex. Photo by Brighton Argus

The aircraft left Gatwick at 11.45am this morning.

The Boeing 747, which was heading for Las Vegas, was then ordered to turn back and was kept in a holding pattern over Gatwick, before landing shortly before 4pm.

Virgin said: ''Virgin Atlantic can confirm that the plane has landed safely at Gatwick. Our priority now is to look after our passengers.''

Ambulances and fire-and-rescue crews had been on standby as the plane circled the airport in the hours after it took off for America in late morning.

Before the successful landing, Virgin announced that the plane would be carrying out a ''non-standard landing procedure'' at Gatwick airport.

Eyewitnesses reported that the jet was flying at a relatively low altitude and that the pilot appeared to be trying to shake the landing gear down.

Flight VS43 makes emergency landing at Gatwick - live coverage >>

Virgin #VS43 landed safely at Gatwick with a landing gear problem 4 hours after departure http://t.co/YsgFN6frqT pic.twitter.com/XyJXY16B8c -- Flightradar24 (@flightradar24)

December 29, 2014
results.title: Virgin Atlantic flight VS43 makes dramatic landing at Gatwick

Flight VS43, bound for Las Vegas, touched back down at the West Sussex just before 4pm.

The flight did indeed fly over Southampton, but not for an inspection.

The plane flying over Sussex. Photo by Brighton Argus

The aircraft left Gatwick at 11.45am this morning.

Virgin said: ''Virgin Atlantic can confirm that the plane has landed safely at Gatwick. Our priority now is to look after our passengers.''

Ambulances and fire-and-rescue crews had been on standby as the plane circled the airport in the hours after it took off for America in late morning.

Before the successful landing, Virgin announced that the plane would be carrying out a ''non-standard landing procedure'' at Gatwick airport.

Eyewitnesses reported that the jet was flying at a relatively low altitude and that the pilot appeared to be trying to shake the landing gear down.

Virgin #VS43 landed safely at Gatwick with a landing gear problem 4 hours after departure http://t.co/YsgFN6frqT pic.twitter.com/XyJXY16B8c -- Flightradar24 (@flightradar24)

results.title: Virgin Atlantic flight VS43 makes dramatic landing at Gatwick

results.body:
A Virgin Atlantic passenger plane has "landed safely" at Gatwick airport after problems with its landing gear, according to air traffic website Flightradar 24.

Earlier the airline said it was "preparing to implement a non-standard landing procedure at Gatwick airport" because of "a technical issue with one of the landing gears".

Virgin said: "Virgin Atlantic can confirm that flight VS43 on December 29, travelling to McCarran International Airport Las Vegas, returned to Gatwick due to a technical issue with one of the landing gears.

"The aircraft is preparing to implement a non-standard landing procedure at Gatwick airport. A further update will be issued as soon as possible."

The plane is a Boeing 747 jumbo jet.

A Gatwick Airport spokesman said: "We can confirm that Virgin Atlantic flight VS043 which departed Gatwick Airport at around 11.45am is returning to Gatwick after the aircraft developed a technical fault.

"In line with standard procedure, emergency services are on standby at the airport purely as a precaution."

Eyewitnesses reported the jet was flying at a relatively low altitude and that the pilot appeared to be trying to shake the landing gear down.
results.title: Passengers applaud as Virgin Atlantic plane lands safely at Gatwick

results.body:
LONDON: Virgin Atlantic flight VS43 has made an emergency landing at London's Gatwick airport, said the airport. Television pictures showed the plane intact and stationary on the runway.

"Virgin Atlantic can confirm that flight VS43 has landed safely back at Gatwick," the company said in a statement. "Our priority now is to look after our passengers and crew."

Earlier Monday (Dec 29), the airline said the passenger plane would carry out a "non-standard landing" at Gatwick airport after a landing gear fault forced the US-bound plane to turn around.

"Flight VS43 ... (has) returned to London Gatwick due to a technical issue with one of the landing gears," Virgin Atlantic said in a statement. "The aircraft is preparing to implement a non-standard landing procedure at Gatwick airport".

The plane departed London Gatwick before midday local time, a spokeswoman for the airport said. Flight-tracking website FightRadar24 said the plane, a Boeing 747-400, left Gatwick at 11.44am local time, about 14 minutes later than planned.
results.title: Virgin Atlantic plane lands safely at Gatwick after fault

results.body:
A Virgin Atlantic passenger plane was today forced to make a 'non-standard landing procedure' at Gatwick airport after developing problems with its landing gear.

Flight VS43, which was en route to Las Vegas, turned back to the West Sussex airport after taking off this morning.

The aircraft circled repeatedly between Gatwick and the South Coast apparently to burn off fuel.

After an anxious wait, the plane landed safely on the tarmac.

According to eyewitnesses, one of the five landing gears on the Boeing 747 jumbo jet had failed to deploy.

Virgin said earlier: 'Virgin Atlantic can confirm that flight VS43 on December 29, travelling to McCarran International Airport Las Vegas, returned to Gatwick due to a technical issue with one of the landing gears.

'The aircraft is preparing to implement a non-standard landing procedure at Gatwick airport. A further update will be issued as soon as possible.'
results.title: Virgin Atlantic plane makes safe landing after landing gear fault

results.body:
LONDON - A Virgin Atlantic jet bound from London to Las Vegas turned back and made an emergency landing at Gatwick Airport on Monday after developing a problem with its landing gear.

The airline confirmed the Boeing 747-400, carrying 447 passengers and 15 crew members, landed safely about four hours after it took off. Television images showed the jet on the runway as fire trucks and ambulances waited nearby.

The plane's emergency chutes were not deployed and there were no immediate reports of injuries. Gatwick said other flights could face delays because the Virgin jet was still on the runway.

The airline said the plane undertook "a non-standard landing procedure" because of "a technical issue with one of the landing gears."

The airport said the flight, VS43, took off at about 11:45 a.m. Monday. Flight-tracking websites show it circled off the coast of southwest England before turning back to Gatwick, south of London. It circled near the airport, and photos appeared to show a set of wheels on its right-side landing gear had not fully descended.

Emergency services were on standby for the landing -- standard procedure when a plane has to land with a technical problem.
results.title: Virgin Atlantic 747 makes emergency landing at Gatwick Airport

The airport said the flight, VS43, took off at about 11:45 a.m. Monday. Flight-tracking websites show it circled off the coast of southwest England before turning back to Gatwick, south of London.
